newsitem.title: ITALY: Italians mourn Versace -- a son who died far away.
newsitem.headline: Italians mourn Versace -- a son who died far away.

text.p: Italians, used to mourning violent death on their own soil, grieved on Wednesday over the murder of fashion king Gianni Versace in a far away city many associate only with television police serials.

But the television tales of cops and criminals turned into grim reality that hit home in a horrific way when Versace was shot twice in the head on the steps of his Miami Beach mansion by a lone gunman.

"This time, the name Miami and all the rest of it evoke in us a real figure, a person whom we knew here in Milan," said the Corriere Della Sera, the main newspaper in the city where the Versace fashion empire was based.
During decades of Mafia and terrorist violence, Italians had become accustomed to seeing their own sons and daughters killed on the streets of Palermo, Rome or Milan.
This time they watched with horror on television as Miami Beach police draped a plastic sheet over the pool of Versace's blood on the sidewalk.
Pictures of paramedics desperately applying cardiac massage to the fashion king on a cold steel ambulance stretcher were splashed on the front pages of all newspapers.
"Versace: Death in Miami" headlined Rome's La Repubblica newspaper, noting the irony of Versace dying in the city he perhaps loved most.
Even newspaper graphics were reminiscent of the coverage of the big Mafia and terrorism crimes years past.

They showed detailed drawings of Versace walking towards his Mediterranean-style villa with a bundle of newspapers under his arms. A man with a gun appears in the next comic book frame and in the third, Versace languishes on the ground.
Still, despite the area's violent image, friends said Versace loved it because of its rhythm, its Latino influence, its ocean breeze and and even its dangerous side.
"Miami was in his heart," La Repubblica said. "He would say 'tomorrow I'm flying to Miami' like other people would say 'I'm going to get a coffee.'
"In Miami, Gianni Versace found death, with a pile of newspapers under his arm, outside his front door," it added.
"He fell on the steps of a villa that should have been a monument to his life and instead will always be the mausoleum of his death," the newspaper said.
As Miami Beach police searched for Andew Cunanan, a 27-year-old male prostitute suspected in the killing, tributes continued to pour in for the man who dressed the world's beautiful people.
Valentino, one of Italy's best-known stylists, wrote a first-person farewell letter to Versace published in Turin's La Stampa newspaper.
"Dear Gianni, they asked me to remember you. I am doing it, broken down and devasted, only because you are a friend in this world of fashion that is often cruel and without rules," he wrote.
"You managed to keep up a sense of great human dignity and fair play that is very rare."
The gala closing of the Rome high fashion shows that was to have been held on Wednesday night on Rome's Spanish Steps was cancelled in a sign of mourning.
On Wednesday morning, tourists visiting the steps found two bunches of roses with notes attached. One was a handwritten poem -- the other simply said: "You are fashion".
